page.title: 18TERRAIN,ULLAPOOL.
page.content: The landscape of this area is the result of erosion, including that of glaciers, on the rock types present. There is a major thrust fault crossing the area, called the Moine Thrust, formed during mountain building. The rocks at Ullapool are Lewisian gneiss,Torridonian sandstone,Cambrian quartzite,grit,limestone and Moine schist.The sequence starts with gneiss which was heavily eroded before the sandstone was deposited.The rest of the Cambrian sediment was then deposited in a shallow sea before the Moine Thrust moved schists over the sequence. The hills to the north of Ullapool have been glaciated then the Ullapool River cut through the hills and formed a gorge.Lochbroom is a fiord cut by a major valley glacier. Higher sea levels cut 2 raised beaches at both Newton Loggie and Ullapool.
